race.name: Great Otway Gravel Grind
race.tagline: Jurassic rainforest and tall tree ferns near Great Ocean Road in Victoria, Australia.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Australian coastal countryside. Moderate elevation with coastal scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Australian event. Coastal terrain with remote access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Great Otway Gravel Grind is a local event in Victoria‚Äîcoastal terrain with moderate elevation. The Australian coastal scenery is scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Australian coastal gravel race. Worth it for Victoria/Australian riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Victoria‚Äîyes, it's good value. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Australian races: Gravel Gong, Dirty Gravel.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Forrest has very limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Forrest has very limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Great Otway Gravel Grind website

non_negotiables.why: Australian coastal conditions require specific preparation.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Mark's first-timer testimonial reveals strong organizational support: "The whole thing really blew me away!" and Shane praises "excellent support and sensational race and event village vibe." The unique rally format with timeout zones and coffee vans shows thoughtful course design, though finish at Forrest Football ground still suggests small-town infrastructure.

length.explanation: The new 106km option hits proper gravel distance while the 49km provides entry-level access. Sayers133's training plan for the previous 97km course - "back to back 4week FTP building plans on zwift followed by an 8week race prep and taper" - shows riders take the distance seriously without venturing into ultra territory. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course features "predominantly smooth hard-packed earth" on 2WD dirt roads that "require minimal technical bike skills" but still challenge riders. The long climb through rainforest on Delany Road demands proper pacing, while organizers recommend 40-45mm tires and tubeless setup for the mixed gravel sections. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The 49km course delivers 1,180m of climbing with a "long and consistent climb through the rainforest" to the high point, while the previous 97km featured "just over 2,000m of climbing." The final 16km descent is described as "magnificent" where "hardly a pedal stroke is needed" - proper elevation reward. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Late February conditions earn consistent "brutal" descriptions from multiple riders including David's race report. Kathryn noted "30 seconds into the race I had a face full of dust," suggesting dry conditions that create challenging riding environments in the Australian summer heat. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: High point over 600m starting from Forrest's low elevation means zero altitude considerations. This remains coastal Victorian hill country where thin air never factors into performance or race strategy. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Ben McDonald captures the setting: "The course takes you through some of the most spectacular scenery you will ever see," winding through "tall timber forests, past massive tree ferns" in the Jurassic-like Otway landscape. The route descends to "turquoise waters of the Southern Ocean" via the Great Ocean Road.

prestige.explanation: Gran Fondo World Tour inclusion and 10th edition status provide some credibility, but the field remains regional. Elite rider Peta Mullens calls it her "favourite course" though no notable competitive winners emerge from the testimonials or race reports available.

race_quality.explanation: The rally format with timeout zones shows innovation, and Mark's 51-year-old first-timer experience - "I'm still on a high 4 days later" - suggests solid execution. However, courses conducted on public roads where "everyone must remain aware" of traffic indicates compromised race conditions.

experience.explanation: Riders consistently describe transformative experiences. Mark's first event "really blew me away" and Ben McDonald notes how "the camaraderie and support from your fellow riders makes it all worth it." The timeout zones with coffee vans create unique social racing opportunities beyond typical gravel events.

community.explanation: Race Director Sam Maffett's rally format philosophy - "mixing race time with social time. Everyone wins!" - creates inclusive atmosphere for 300+ riders. The 20th anniversary Otway Odyssey weekend with retro celebrations and multi-race options builds broader community engagement beyond single-day racing.

field_depth.explanation: Field includes recreational riders like Sayers133 doing their first race and age-group participants like 51-year-old Mark, with elite presence limited to Peta Mullens testimonials. The timeout zone format accommodates varying abilities but doesn't attract deep competitive fields. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Inclusivity puts it: "Whether you're an elite chomping at the bit to 'win the big one', an age-grouper looking to battle it out for podiums, a newbie wanting to try your hand in the 30km MTB, or a social-rider wanting to c..."

value.explanation: Multi-race discounts of 40% and first 1000 entrants receiving commemorative multi-tools show reasonable pricing structure. The rally format adds unique value - riders can "stop and wait for a friend, consume calories or purchase coffee" without time penalties, creating social racing unavailable elsewhere.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100 AUD. Equipment recommendations include 40-45mm tubeless tires, quality chain lube for 4-6 hour events, and avoiding lightweight bottle cages on gravel roads. The Forrest location requires travel planning for most riders, though multi-event weekend packages help distribute costs across multiple race experiences. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Great Otway Gravel Grind 2026 ‚Äì COURSE PREVIEW
videos.description:
Ready to take on the challenge of the Great Otway Gravel Grind? Get the inside scoop on the NEW 106km course for the 2026 GOGG! Join Rapid Ascent's Sam Maffett & Jez Baker as they explore the world-class circuit, from the prehistoric forests to the stunning Great Ocean Road coastline.

Whether you're a seasoned gravel grinder or looking for your next big adventure, this course preview will give you a taste of what you'll soak up in the GOGG. Learn about the key climbs, the thrilling descents, and the unique rally format with timed and untimed sections. Get ready to ride!

COURSE DETAILS:

‚Ä¢ Event: Great Otway Gravel Grind (GOGG)
‚Ä¢ Distance: 106km
‚Ä¢ Elevation: 2,750m
‚Ä¢ Date: Sunday, 1st March 2026
‚Ä¢ Start/Finish: Forrest Football Ground, Forrest, Victoria

videos.title: Great Otway Gravel Grind Reccy Part 1...FAIL
videos.description:
his is Part 1 of my attempt to complete the Rapid Ascent Great Otway Gravel Grind ‚Äì the new 106 km route through the heart of the Otways.

Starting in Forrest, this ride takes us through the incredible contrast the Otways offer ‚Äî dense forest, open ridgelines, long gravel roads, and moments of quiet effort.

In this first chapter, the ride carries me through:

Lardners Climb

Old Bay Road descent

Seaview Ridge Road, with some of the best views in the Otways

At 74 km in, the ride comes to an abrupt halt ‚Äî a mechanical setback with a seized freehub brings this chapter to a close.

This isn‚Äôt about racing or results.
It‚Äôs about effort, problem-solving, and staying present when plans unravel.

Part 2 picks up from here.

If you ride gravel, love wild places, or use movement as a way to clear your head ‚Äî you‚Äôre in the right place.

Ride along.

‚Äî Gravel Dad

videos.title: The Great Otway Gravel Grind (GOGG)
videos.description:
This week we sit down for a chat with Sam Maffett from Rapid Ascent Event Management, organisers of one of Australia‚Äôs Premier mass participation Gravel Race events. Run in conjunction with the famous Otway Odyssey Marathon Mountain bike race and starting and finishing in the tiny township of Forrest in the heart of the Otway Ranges, the GOGG offers riders the option of 97km or 49km courses.

Join us as we discuss the event, and explore the place of gravel racing and mass start events in the wider Australian gravel scene. 

For more information on the GOGG, or to register for this year‚Äôs event on the 26th of February, head to https://gogg.rapidascent.com.au/

Please follow or subscribe to this podcast so you don‚Äôt miss any of our upcoming episodes, and if possible, please leave us a rating or review to help other gravel cyclists find us!

Follow us on Insta at https://instagram.com/the_gravel_cycling_aus_podcast?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

If you have any feedback or suggestions, Please DM us or send us an email at thegravelcyclingpodcast@gmail.com




Support the show (https://www.buzzsprout.com/2078888/support) 


Please follow or subscribe to this podcast so you don‚Äôt miss any of our upcoming episodes, and if possible, please leave us a rating or review to help other gravel cyclists find us!

Follow us on Insta at https://instagram.com/the_gravel_cycling_aus_podcast?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

If you have any feedback or suggestions, please DM us or send us an email at thegravelcyclingpodcast@gmail.com.

If you're in the Melbourne area and looking for a gravel ride to join, try out Northern Groadies - https://www.strava.com/clubs/954277/group_events/1334459

And finally - I love putting this Podcast together - Chatting with like minded people about gravel cycling is about as good as it gets!

And hopefully, this independent content brings you plenty of value too üòÅ

If it does, and you are in a position to do so, I'd really appreciate it if you could help us out by becoming a supporter of the show! 

Turns out there is a lot of work, and a fairly significant financial cost, involved in creating, editing and publishing a Podcast - your support will help cover these costs and ensure we (I!) can keep bringing you high quality content. Thanks!!

videos.title: Great Otway Gravel Grind 2022
videos.description:
Ride a magical line through the Otway Ranges - Sunday 22 February 2022!

When it comes to gravel grinding this is A-grade riding on A-grade dirt roads made accessible to all types of riders.

Escape the asphalt and dig-the-dirt of traffic-free roads as they wind through tall timber forests and massive tree fern, past lookouts, lakes and beaches on a magical ride with plenty of fresh air.

Now in its 5th year, the GOGG is fast gaining recognition as one of Australia‚Äôs best gravel events. Join us in 2022!

videos.title: Great Otway Gravel Grind 2020 Highlights Reel
videos.description:
The 4th edition of the Great Otway Gravel Grind took over 300 riders on a stunning journey through the Otway Ranges to the coast and back. 

Conducted on smooth rolling dirt roads, the event included a Big Ring 97km course, and a Small Ring 49km course both starting and finishing in Forrest, Victoria.

Perfect race conditions made for a hard and fast track and some lightning pace setters in all categories.

Congratulations to Tasman Nankervis and Peta Mullens who won the respective Men's and Women's titles for the 97km Big Ring circuit.

Thanks to Matt Hull from The Matt Image for the highlights reel.

quotes.text: So the way ordeal does come to an end at the summit of Mount Sabine. You've got three challenges to overcome - a steep, sometimes muddy, very rarely dry ramp through the forest, then ruts and mud holes like landmines where it's a matter of choosing your line through, and finally this ramp through the rainforest that gets you to the summit.

The reason why it's such quality gravel throughout all four seasons is it just doesn't get the sun. We don't get those massive corrugations through here and stays relatively compact. Obviously Forrest is the wettest part of Victoria.

Look at this place - we are surrounded by tall fern trees, mountain ash, myrtle forest. It's lush country through here at the 45km mark. It's sort of a technical kind of ride, real twisty, turny, the gravel is hard packed but a little bit rough in parts.

key_challenges.name: Road Knight Creek Road climb
key_challenges.description: 15 kilometer steady climb at 3-4% grade after legs are warmed up. Riders emphasize finding rhythm and not getting carried away early. Compact gravel with loose sections in the middle.

key_challenges.name: Ladness Track climb
key_challenges.description: Final section climbing to 540m above sea level. Described as steady 3-4% grade where you find your gear, find your rhythm, and just breathe. Considered one of the most beautiful climbs.

key_challenges.name: Technical descent to Apollo Bay
key_challenges.description: Long technical descent that's twisty and turny with sharp turns in places. Fast and flowy but requires line choice. Hard packed gravel that's a little rough in parts.

key_challenges.name: Wild Dog Road climb
key_challenges.description: 19 kilometer climb from sea level at Apollo Bay to Mount Sabine summit, the highest point of the course. Starts as ashphalt then continues uphill through rainforest.

key_challenges.name: The Otway Ordeal (Sabine Slog)
key_challenges.description: Three-stage challenge in final kilometer to Mount Sabine summit: steep sometimes muddy ramp through forest, section with ruts and mud holes like landmines requiring line choice, and final ramp through rainforest to summit.

terrain_notes.text: Gravel quality stays compact throughout all seasons because the forest doesn't get sun, preventing massive corrugations. Forest Victoria is the wettest part of Victoria so surface stays relatively stable.
Hard packed gravel that's a little rough in parts but easy going for a good quality gravel bike. Some sections have loose gravel in the middle as expected.
Ridge Track descent is a bit loose with tight turns and corrugations on the inside of turns, requiring careful line choice.

gear_mentions.text: Don't recommend anything that's got too much tread through the middle of the tire. Cuado Gravel MS tires mentioned as what not to use.

race_day_tips.text: Be ready for the little climb at the very beginning up Yoga Street right off the start line - it's a pinch that can cause chain drops and let the front pack get away.
On the 15k Road Knight Creek Road climb, get yourself tucked in, find your rhythm, settle in, and don't get too carried away early when your legs are just getting warm.
Timeout zones stop your time so you can wait for friends, check tire pressure, have something to drink, and enjoy food. Use these strategically at the 27k mark and at Apollo Bay.

additional_quotes.text: Everyone can line up side by side at the start line with national champions or international riders as well as first timers all out there stoked to ride bikes and that's sort of what it's all about for me
Registration is at the football ground at Yoga where the finish line is and all that kind of thing. Head through Forest to start with.

rider_intel.search_text: The Great Otway Gravel Grind features two major climbs that define the race experience. The first is a 15-kilometer steady climb on Road Knight Creek Road at 3-4% grade starting around the 9-mile mark, followed by the Ladness Track section climbing to 540m elevation. The course includes a long technical descent to Apollo Bay with twisty turns and sharp corners on hard-packed but rough gravel. The signature challenge is the Otway Ordeal near mile 50 - a three-stage climb to Mount Sabine summit featuring steep muddy ramps, rutted sections requiring careful line choice, and a final push through rainforest. The gravel quality remains compact year-round due to limited sun exposure in the wet Otway forests, though some sections have loose material in the middle. Timeout zones at key points stop race time for regrouping and nutrition. The race starts and finishes at Forrest Football Ground with early ashphalt sections before transitioning to forest gravel roads through mountain ash and rainforest terrain.
